name: 2-phenylhydroquinone
Reason: 2-phenylhydroquinone has a melting point influenced by the functional groups relative to the base melting point of benzene, which is around 5°C. The basic unit for comparison can be benzene, which has a melting point of 5.5°C (according to the CRC Handbook of Chemistry and Physics, 49th Edition, 1968-1969). The structural modifications we need to consider are the presence of two additional phenyl groups. Phenyl groups, when connected to a benzene ring, tend to increase the melting point due to the enhancement of the crystalline structure and the increase in molecular weight. In the case of 2-phenylhydroquinone, we have two additional phenyl groups linked in a linear fashion, which would notably augment the melting point. Each additional phenyl group can be estimated to add approximately 100°C to the melting point due to increased pi-pi interactions, rigidity, and molecular weight.
